problem_text:
Let Γ be an infinite directed graph, and Γ the underlying undirected graph. Suppose that the graph Γ admits a vertex-transitive group of automorphisms, and the graph Γ is connected and of finite valency. Does there exist a positive integer k (possibly depending on Γ) such that for any positive integer n there is a directed path of length at most k · n in the graph Γ whose initial and terminal vertices are at distance at least n in the graph Γ?
Comment of 2005: It is proved that there exists a positive integer k′ (depending only on the valency of Γ) such that for any positive integer n there is a directed path of length at most k′ · n2 in the graph Γ whose initial and terminal vertices are at distance at least n in the graph Γ (V. I. Trofimov, Europ. J. Combinatorics, 27, no. 5 (2006), 690–700).
V. I. Trofimov
